subtitle: i remember a number of years ago
after one of my classes we were sitting
around a group of four or five of us
talking about life people were sharing
their own personal experiences
one of the people was an obstetrician
in his 40s and he shared something that
remains with me
very moving he said he worked in new
york hospital
in manhattan new york city
and his job he delivers children
delivers babies
the eighth floor of new york hospital
the new york hospital is situated right
over the fdr
it's a thoroughfare filled with a lot of
traffic
it says sometimes i'm delivering a child
it's the middle of the day very busy you
hear the rush hour
horns honking brakes screeching
you can sense tempers flaring and i'm
delivering a baby here in the quiet of
the room sometimes it's the middle of
the night
it's quieter and i contrast
very often where are people rushing to
they're rushing to get home they're
rushing to go to dinner
they're rushing to our program to our
show and here i have the privilege
to be able to deliver a child the
miracle of life itself the miracle of
beginnings
while people are rushing maybe important
things some most people are rushing just
to rush
and it brings me to tears that i'm
privileged to be part of the miracle
and here there's no bumper-to-bumper
traffic it's a mother
an attending nurse myself the doctor
maybe another person or two
no one's lining up there's no
bumper-to-bumper traffic nobody's
rushing to come to see this miracle
i decided to drive home that night on
the fdr
and i was thinking about his words we're
all in our rush hours
some literally some metaphorically
but it reminded me what the bashamtv
said the difference between a miracle
and a natural event
is only frequency if the sun were to
rise once in
our lifetimes we'd say what a miracle
we'd come out with camera crews and our
children
look at this ball rising in the horizon
but since it happens every morning
ah big thing so a miracle is
essentially nature it's just a bunch of
miracles happening in repeated ways
that can convince us and dilute us into
thinking
it's just a monotonous repetition
when in truth every moment is a miracle
every breath is a miracle
you don't appreciate it until you see
someone who's struggling to breathe
every breath that's the way to look
at life you are a miracle your life is a
miracle
every detail of it is a miracle it's
just we
the person gets bored we can be the
issue
not the miracle we're not appreciating
that
which is happening in our lives and
around us
and when you do you're redeeming
and elevating those sparks
